docs.lead_paragraph: For scores of women in the epicenter of the Zika outbreak in Brazil, the joy of pregnancy has given way to fear.

docs.lead_paragraph: Andy Murray had one thing on his mind as he walked off the court with the Australian Open runner-up trophy, yet again: Would he make his early-morning flight back to Britain to be with his wife Kim, who is about to give birth to their first child?

headline.main: Distracted Murray Comes Up Short Again in Melbourne
headline.print_headline: Distracted Murray Comes Up Short Again in Melbourne

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a third of pregnant women with the mosquito-borne illness are in a single province, the nation’s health institute said.

headline.main: Colombia Reports More Than 2,100 Pregnant Women Have Zika Virus

docs.lead_paragraph: Syrian Christianity, threatened with destruction, still has secrets to reveal.

headline.main: Is This the Oldest Image of the Virgin Mary?
headline.print_headline: Is This the Oldest Image of the Virgin Mary?

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Michael Peppard describes how painting at Yale University Art Gallery, excavated in 1932 in eastern Syria, may in fact be oldest known image of Virgin Mary; notes painting was long thought to depict so-called Samaritan Woman; warns of way Islamic State group's plundering of sites like one where painting was discovered threatens further understanding and preservation of artifacts from early Syrian Christianity.
docs.snippet: Syrian Christianity, threatened with destruction, still has secrets to reveal.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zika virus is spreading rapidly in Latin America, and Asian governments have issued advisories in a bid to contain the mosquito-borne disease, which could be linked to birth defects and can cause temporary paralysis.

headline.main: Asian Countries Urge Sick Travelers to Report Zika Symptoms
headline.print_headline: Asian Countries Urge Sick Travelers to Report Zika Symptoms

docs.snippet: The Zika virus is spreading rapidly in Latin America, and Asian governments have issued advisories in a bid to contain the mosquito-borne disease, which could be linked to birth defects and can cause temporary paralysis.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zika epidemic has spread much faster than science’s understanding of it.

headline.main: Tears and Bewilderment in Brazilian City Facing Zika Crisis
headline.print_headline: Tears and Bewilderment at Center of Zika Crisis

docs.abstract: Zika virus is spreading at unprecedented rate in Brazil, stunning doctors and leaving even most experienced among them scrambling as birth defects surge; researchers believe as many as 1.5 million people have been infected in Brazil since 2014, and say virus has spread to more than 20 countries and territories in Americas.
docs.snippet: The Zika epidemic has spread much faster than science’s understanding of it.

byline.contributor: Vinod Sreeharsha contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro.

docs.lead_paragraph: O New York Times gostaria de ouvir a opinião de mulheres que deram à luz recentemente, que estejam grávidas ou planejando engravidar, e estão preocupadas com o vírus Zika.

headline.main: Como o vírus Zika tem afetado você?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zika virus is spreading rapidly in Latin America, and Asian governments have issued advisories in a bid to contain the spread of the disease, which could be linked to birth defects and can cause temporary paralysis. So far, no Zika case has been confirmed anywhere in Asia.

headline.main: Asian Countries Urge Sick Travelers to Report Zika Symptoms

docs.lead_paragraph: Global health officials say the Zika virus, linked to severe birth defects in thousands of babies in Brazil, is spreading rapidly in the Americas and could infect 3 million to 4 million people. The race is on to develop a Zika vaccine.

headline.main: Factbox: Why the Zika Virus Is Causing Alarm in the Americas
headline.print_headline: Factbox: Why the Zika Virus Is Causing Alarm in the Americas

docs.snippet: Global health officials say the Zika virus, linked to severe birth defects in thousands of babies in Brazil, is spreading rapidly in the Americas and could infect 3 million to 4 million people. The race is on to develop a Zika vaccine.
